TEXT.English: [H1]Congresses[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses in Rhye's and Fall represent the phenomenon of informal institutionalization of international politics that began during the 19th century. This includes the idea of the balance of power which manifested itself in the Congress of Vienna and the Concert of Europe, but also international conferences on territorial claims such as the Berlin Congress. They also represent other diplomatic exchanges of territory like the Louisiana Purchase.[PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses take place as soon as the first civilization discovers Nationalism and regularly occur every 15 turns. The ten most powerful civilizations of the world will be invited, and each of them can either claim a city or request to found a colony on unsettled territory. If the majority of civilizations agrees, the request is granted and the city will change hands or a settler will be created on the demanded empty spot. While the human player can decide on claims by voting YES, NO or ABSTAIN, the AI will make its own decisions based on a variety of factors. These include the legitimacy of the claim (e.g. if the claimed city is historical for the civilization or if it already has culture there), the relationship to the demanding and controlling civilizations, including their own interest in the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]If a player claim was considered legitimate by an AI, but not granted because of insufficient relations, or if a player city has been granted to another civilization by the AI, the player can choose a number of options to influence the vote of AI civilizations in their favor. This can happen either through bribery (offering gold) or manipulation (expending espionage points). The player can spend varying amounts of both resources depending on how much they consider influencing their votes necessary. Another way to influence the AI is by agreeing to their own claims in the same congress - or at least avoiding to vote against them![PARAGRAPH:2]If all attempts fail and the congress still gives away one of your cities, you still have the opportunity to refuse handing it over. But be careful, this may cause some of the civilizations that agreed to the request to go to war over your contempt for their decision! The more votes were in favor of reassigning the city, the likelier an individual civilization is to go to war.[PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses are disrupted by global wars, under which different rules apply. A global war takes place when at least half the military power of the world is at war with each other. During these times, no congresses occur because the world is settling its differences on the battlefield instead of the negotiation table. However, when such a global war ends (by the main belligerents agreeing to peace), peace is enforced on all belligerents and a new congress is called to restore order after the war. Such a congress differs from normal congresses in that only belligerents are invited, that only civilizations on the winning side are allowed to make demands, and that it is impossible to request colonizing free territory. Civilizations that have lost the war still can vote on all claims, however. Congresses completely come to an end when the United Nations are built because their formalized approach to multilateral diplomacy makes congresses obsolete. [NEWLINE]If you are familiar with Congresses from Rhye's and Fall, you will notice multiple significant changes and improvements over the previous system, some of which have already been mentioned: [ICON_BULLET]In addition to periodic congresses, congresses can also occur after global wars [ICON_BULLET]Participants can also request to settle free territory [ICON_BULLET]A streamlined interaction process so that the entire congress can be resolved in one turn [ICON_BULLET]Significant improvements in computation times [ICON_BULLET]When voting on a claim, the camera centers on the plot or city in question [ICON_BULLET]The option to influence a civilization's decision is only offered when there is actually a chance of success [ICON_BULLET]Attempts to influence a decision are now specific to a certain claim and can be used both to achieve agreement to an own claim and disagreement with a claim on your own cities [ICON_BULLET]There is no limit on how many civilizations can be attempted to be influenced during the same Congress [ICON_BULLET]In addition to bribery by offering gold, votes can also be manipulated by expending espionage [ICON_BULLET]More sophisticated AI decisionmaking: it now takes the legitimacy of the claim, its relations to the claimant and owner, and its own interest in the city into account [ICON_BULLET]More global AI decisionmaking: your own voting behavior influences how the AI treats your claims and the claims against you, global opinion influences how likely AIs are to go to war over a refused claim [ICON_BULLET]No more multiple assignments during the same Congress: if more than one civilization have successfully claimed the same city, it goes to the civilization that received the most votes in favor

TEXT.English: [H1]Continents, Countries and Unique Historical Victories[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye has split the World Map into separate continents. No longer will a wonder built in China have an effect on a city in South Africa. With this magic, Rhye also further subdivided the world into countries, even assigning historically accurate city names to individual tiles. These names will be your guide for the UHVs. For most of the territory UHVs (Control the Balkans, Control Mesopotamia, etc.) you will be required to control up to 3 cities in the area. Rome is the most stringent, requiring 2 cities in Iberia, 3 cities in Gaul, 1 city in Britain, 2 cities in Africa, 4 cities in Greece and Byzantium and 2 cities in Egypt.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Dawn of Civilization, the regions that pertain to your UHV are shown in the tile tooltip when hovering over the relevant tiles.

TEXT.English: [H1]Diplomatic Institutions[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The [BOLD]Apostolic Palace[\BOLD] and [BOLD]United Nations[\BOLD] have seen some changes in Dawn of Civilizations. Several rules have been modified and certain resolutions were to increase their impact and make them more interesting to interact with. General changes: [ICON_BULLET]Instead of being directly proportional to population, the number of votes of a civilization are now proportional to the square root of its population. This reduces the influence of large civilizations and makes cooperation with smaller civilizations more important. [ICON_BULLET]Defying resolutions now follows different rules for the two institutions. [ICON_BULLET]When a civilization attempts to win a diplomatic victory, its own votes and the votes of its vassals are disregarded. Instead it needs to win a majority among the remaining votes. This way, the diplomatic victory truly requires diplomacy, and cannot be achieved by military subjugation. [H2]Apostolic Palace[\H2] [ICON_BULLET]Apostolic Palace elections triggered by constructing Saint Peter's Basilica [ICON_BULLET]Only civilizations with Catholic state religions are members of the Apostolic Palace and allowed to vote. [ICON_BULLET]Resolutions that affect all members don't fail only because a member defies it. [ICON_BULLET]Instead, civilizations defying resolutions are not affected by them. The usual penalties (loss of membership, unhappiness, diplomatic penalties) still apply. [ICON_BULLET]Renamed the "Declare War" resolutions to "Crusade". Valid targets are non-members who are at war with a member (defensive crusade) and non-members who control the Catholic holy city or shrine (offensive crusade). [ICON_BULLET]New "Collect Tithe" resolution: all members pay 10% of their treasury of which the Pope receives half. [ICON_BULLET]New "Send Inquisition" resolution: the Pope receives additional espionage against the target civilization. [ICON_BULLET]New "Excommunication" resolution: the target loses membership and receives unhappiness as if they had defied a resolution. [H2]United Nations[\H2] [ICON_BULLET]Security Council: only the four civilizations with the highest military power are allowed to defy resolutions. [ICON_BULLET]New "Decolonize City" resolution: Cities on other continents can be forced to be liberated to independents. [ICON_BULLET]New "Release Civilization" resolution: If a civilization can respawn, another civilization controlling their territory can be forced to release it.

[H2]Apostolic Palace[\H2] [ICON_BULLET]Apostolic Palace elections triggered by constructing Saint Peter's Basilica [ICON_BULLET]Only civilizations with Catholic state religions are members of the Apostolic Palace and allowed to vote. [ICON_BULLET]Resolutions that affect all members don't fail only because a member defies it. [ICON_BULLET]Instead, civilizations defying resolutions are not affected by them. The usual penalties (loss of membership, unhappiness, diplomatic penalties) still apply. [ICON_BULLET]Renamed the "Declare War" resolutions to "Crusade". Valid targets are non-members who are at war with a member (defensive crusade) and non-members who control the Catholic holy city or shrine (offensive crusade). [ICON_BULLET]New "Collect Tithe" resolution: all members pay 10% of their treasury of which the Pope receives half. [ICON_BULLET]New "Send Inquisition" resolution: the Pope receives additional espionage against the target civilization. [ICON_BULLET]New "Excommunication" resolution: the target loses membership and receives unhappiness as if they had defied a resolution. [H2]United Nations[\H2] [ICON_BULLET]Security Council: only the four civilizations with the highest military power are allowed to defy resolutions. [ICON_BULLET]New "Decolonize City" resolution: Cities on other continents can be forced to be liberated to independents. [ICON_BULLET]New "Release Civilization" resolution: If a civilization can respawn, another civilization controlling their territory can be forced to release it.

TEXT.English: [H1]Golden Ages[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]During certain periods of time, some civilizations seem to burst with energy and creativity. The civilization's people become increasingly productive; technological advances come easy to the civilization; and its culture is the envy of the world. Italy during the Renaissance is one such example, and Great Britain in the 19th century another. In Civilization IV, such periods are called "golden ages."[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Entering a Golden Age[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wonders:[\BOLD] A civilization can enter a golden age by constructing the [LINK=BUILDING_TAJ_MAHAL]Taj Mahal[\LINK] wonder.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Great People:[\BOLD] A civilization can combine one or more [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great People[\LINK] of different types to start a golden age. The cost of this method escalates: the first golden age costs one great person, the second costs two, the third one cost three, and so on.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Golden Ages[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]During a golden age, your civilization greatly increases its output of production and commerce, meaning faster build times and research rates. (In game terms, every space within your city's radii that provides commerce produces an extra commerce, and every space that provides production now produces an additional one.) [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duration of Golden Ages[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Golden ages last eight turns on Normal Speed. If you achieve another golden age while in the midst of one already, the eight additional turns are tacked onto the end of the present golden age. You may increase the length of your Golden Ages by controlling the [LINK=BUILDING_MAUSOLEUM_OF_MAUSSOLLOS]Mausoleum of Maussollos[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]The End of the Age[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Once the golden age ends, your civilization's commerce and production return to normal levels.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.English: [H1]Historical Starts[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]This is why your game won't start immediately for most Civs. Rhye's mod, above all else, was designed to mirror history. As such, most civs spawn many years into the game, as late as 1822 for Brazil. If you want to play as a late spawning civ now, load up one of the quick starts. Don't worry about being behind; you will start with many units and techs to place you on an even footing with the AIs.[PARAGRAPH:2]In addition to all those units and techs, you may even have some cities flip for you. Although, be aware when playing imperialistic civilizations such as Persia, Rome and Arabia. New civs will carve their empires out of your land! If you refuse to let go of the cities, units in the area will join the resistance for several turns. If you decide to resist the wave of nationalism, make sure your army is large enough to handle defectors!

TEXT.English: [H1]Mercenaries[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The Mercenary screen can be accessed by clicking the small axe icon in the upper left of the screen. Here you can hire foreign units for your wars. Be warned that it takes several turns for the units to appear in your cities. Also, you can offer your own units for hire by clicking the hand with scroll icon while a unit is in a city. Mercenaries become obsolete after the discovery of Nationalism.

TEXT.English: [H1]Mercenaries[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Mercenaries are soldiers who fight primarily for private gain, usually with little regard for ideological, national, political, or moral considerations. However, when the term is used to refer to a soldier in a regular national army, it is usually considered an insult.[PARAGRAPH:2][PARAGRAPH:2]Mercenaries have seen regular deployment in battle since the time of Ancient Egypt and Carthage, up through the 16th century, including the famous Swiss Guard and the Landsknechts. In the game, Mercenaries can be hired only until the discovery of Nationalism, which changed the conception of armies and caused a rapid decline in Mercenary usage.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.English: [H1]Corporations in Dawn of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Corporation headquarters and executives have been removed in Dawn of Civilization. Instead, corporations spread on their own to cities that can attract them. To be able to attract a corporation, you need to have the associated technology and control at least one of the consumed resources. The chance increases by acquiring more resources, constructing appropriate buildings or adopting the Free Market civic. The number of cities per corporation is limited, so corporations can also leave one city and move to another that fulfills its requirements better. Certain corporations also compete with each other, reducing the chance of being present in the same city.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Silk Route and Trading Company corporations behave differently from the others. They don't require the Corporation technology to spread to your cities, but are limited to certain historical regions of the map. Also, they expire after a certain date and start to leave your cities.

TEXT.English: [H1]Plague[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The most controversial and bemoaned addition to this mod, Plague has made RFC more dynamic than even Stability. There are 5 pre-determined Plague spawns. They occur roughly at 400AD, 1300AD, 1650AD and 1850AD. There is a fifth plague that spawns only in Meso-America when Europeans first make contact. This is meant to simulate the spread of Smallpox. But fear not! There are many ways for you to control the spread and duration of the plague.[PARAGRAPH:2]Plague spreads through foreign contact and proximity to infected cities. You can limit this spread by canceling open borders and limiting your trade connections. The major determining factor in catching plague is your health surplus. Having far more health bonuses than unhealthiness will prevent the plague from spreading to your cities. Even if you don't reach the preventative threshold, high health will lessen the duration and severity of the plague. Granaries, Baths, Wharfs and Pharmacies are all vital to any populous empire. Even with these precautions, once a city catches plague, there is little you can do to prevent the spread to neighboring cities. Discovering Microbiology will stop the plague from spreading regardless of your healthiness.

TXT_KEY_CONCEPT_REFORMATION_PEDIA [H1]Reformation[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The Protestant religion is not founded like the other religions. Instead, the discovery of Printing Press by a civilization with Catholic state religion triggers the Reformation. All Catholic civilizations then have to decide if they want to convert to Protestantism and gain additional gold from the dissolution of monasteries, foregoing the benefits of the Apostolic Palace. When a civilization decides to convert, all of its cities immediately change their religion to Protestantism. Large cities also have a chance of keeping Catholicism or gaining Protestantism regardless of your decision.

TEXT.English: [H1]Rebirths and Resurrections in Dawn of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]There are different mechanics for collapsed civilizations to return into the game. Resurrection refers to the rules already present in vanilla RFC that allow a civilization to return if its core is controlled by independents or an unstable civilization. This effect is limited to certain periods in Dawn of Civilization, to prevent ahistorical respawns of ancient and classical civs. Also, it's not necessary to discover Nationalism to enable this mechanism, although it increases the probability of resurrections. This means that you will see resurrections occur earlier in the game. Outside of periodic checks, these resurrections can also occur when an unstable civilization collapses - if their territory includes the core of a civilization that can return, these cities will become part of this civilization instead of being independent.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization also adds another mechanic that is referred to as rebirths. These are scripted and return a specific dead civ at specific dates, if certain conditions are met. Also, the faction now represents a completely new civilization with UU, UB, UP and UHV. Players can take control of these civilizations and complete their victory goals by switching to them, even if they have switched once already. Currently, this mechanic covers the rebirths of Persia as Iran, Maya as Colombia and Aztecs as Mexico.

TEXT.English: [H1]Welcome to Rhye's and Fall of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:0]v1.187[PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye's and Fall of Civilization is a mod based on a map of the world, that attempts to make your single-player game a realistic simulator of history on Earth. It is the sequel to "Rhye's of Civilization", one of the most popular modpacks for Civilization III. [PARAGRAPH:2]The mod revolves around the historic rise and fall of civilizations: they won't start all at the same time, but at appropriate dates. The human player can choose a late start (waiting for the game to play by itself) or take the control of one of the early civs and switch to another one later on. Civilizations will fall by many factors, including civil wars caused by inner instability, and scripted barbarian attacks.[PARAGRAPH:2]Each civilization is heavily differentiated from the others, thanks to the UPs (Unique Powers), the UHVs (Unique Historical Victory conditions), and a unique AI that will found cities in their historical place, with their historical name.[PARAGRAPH:2]Other additions include plague outbreaks, embassies, world congresses where cities are traded, dynamic spread of the resources, and new flag and terrain graphics.[PARAGRAPH:2]More detailed info is provided in the readme. For any other question you can visit the official site (http://rhye.civfanatics.net), the development forum (http://forums.civfanatics.com/forumdisplay.php?f=204) or the wiki (http://rhye.civfanatics.net/wiki/), which contains useful strategy guides.

TEXT.English: [H1]The Great Christian Schism[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Similar to Protestantism, Catholicism is founded by a special event and does not require only a technology. This event is referred to as the Great Schism. It can be triggered in two different ways. After any civilization has first adopted Orthodoxy as its state religion, Catholicism will be founded as soon as there are more Orthodox cities outside of civilizations with Orthodox state religion than within their control. A common scenario for this is the collapse of the Roman civilization, which often leaves many Orthodox cities under independent control (who have no state religion). This represents the establishment of an independent Papacy after most of Christendom slips out of control of secular rulers (historically, the Byzantine Empire). In this case, the largest previously Orthodox city not under Orthodox control becomes the new Catholic holy city.[PARAGRAPH:2]In case this scenario never comes to pass, the Great Schism will also be triggered by the first civilization to build an Orthodox Cathedral without controlling the Orthodox holy city. This represents how more powerful religious leaders emerge outside of the traditional center of Orthodoxy and begin to establish their own separate tradition. In this case, the city with the Cathedral also becomes the Catholic holy city.[PARAGRAPH:2]In either situation, cities convert from Orthodoxy to Catholicism (including buildings) if they are closer to the Catholic than to the Orthodox holy city. An exception are cities under the control of civilizations with Orthodox state religion (in the first scenario) or within the same civilization as the Orthodox holy city (in the second scenario), which will always remain Orthodox.

A common scenario for this is the collapse of the Roman civilization, which often leaves many Orthodox cities under independent control (who have no state religion). This represents the establishment of an independent Papacy after most of Christendom slips out of control of secular rulers (historically, the Byzantine Empire). In this case, the largest previously Orthodox city not under Orthodox control becomes the new Catholic holy city.[PARAGRAPH:2]In case this scenario never comes to pass, the Great Schism will also be triggered by the first civilization to build an Orthodox Cathedral without controlling the Orthodox holy city. This represents how more powerful religious leaders emerge outside of the traditional center of Orthodoxy and begin to establish their own separate tradition. In this case, the city with the Cathedral also becomes the Catholic holy city.[PARAGRAPH:2]In either situation, cities convert from Orthodoxy to Catholicism (including buildings) if they are closer to the Catholic than to the Orthodox holy city. An exception are cities under the control of civilizations with Orthodox state religion (in the first scenario) or within the same civilization as the Orthodox holy city (in the second scenario), which will always remain Orthodox.

TEXT.English: [H1]Slavery[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization aims to represent the transatlantic slave trade as part of the Columbian Exchange. To this purpose, a slave unit has been added to the game. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Creating slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Slaves cannot be trained like other units. Instead they can be created using the "enslave" button in the city screen, which takes the place of the draft button where it is available. This button is only available for civs that use the Slavery civic in cities that are situated in Sub-Saharan Africa and have a population of at least six. Like the draft action, enslaving costs one unit of population and three unhappiness, and creates a slave unit in this city.Slaves can also be acquired by defeating Impis and Pombos. If the battle took place on your territory and you are using Slavery, there is a chance that you will get a slave unit afterwards.Another alternative is purchasing slaves by trade from other civilizations, using the slave trade option of the diplomacy screen, which is explained below. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Trading slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]It is possible to acquire slaves by trade, which allows civilizations that don't have access to cities in Africa to use slaves. Trade can be conducted through the usual diplomacy interface; if the civilization you are talking to has available slave units, they appear on their side of the negotiation table and can be bought just like any other item. The same is true for the units you own. If you have adopted the Egalitarianism civic, slave trade becomes unavailable to you. Civilizations place value on slaves depending on if they have a use for them, i.e. if they have colonies in the Americas or Africa. On the other hand, native African civilizations will not buy slaves. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Using slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The use of slaves is limited by geographical region: they can only be used in the Americas, or in Sub-Saharan Africa unless the civilization has its capital there. Slaves can be used in the following ways: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Build a slave plantation:[\BOLD] the slave can build a slave plantation on all tiles that have a resource which requires a plantation, yielding +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] and +2 [ICON_COMMERCE] compared to a normal plantation. The slave is used in the process, similar to a work boat. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Join city as a slave specialist:[\BOLD] the slave can permanently join the city as a slave specialist, yielding 2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] and creating 1 [ICON_UNHAPPY]. The number of slaves per city is limited to half of its population. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Freeing the slaves[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Both uses of the slave unit (plantations and specialists) can only continue as long as you are not running the Egalitarianism civic. As soon as you adopt Egalitarianism, all slave plantations on your territory will revert to normal plantations, and all slave specialists in your cities will be lost permanently. When a civilization running Egalitarianism gains control of a slave plantation, the improvement reverts to a normal plantation. Slave specialists are always removed on city conquest. If the conquering civilization is running Egalitarianism, these slaves are lost permanently. Otherwise the conqueror receives an equal amount of slave units with the opportunity of settling them elsewhere.[PARAGRAPH]The adoption of Egalitarianism by other civilizations increases the amount of unhappiness created by slaves, creating a growing incentive to adopt Egalitarianism as well to combat the unhappiness from slavery. [NEWLINE][BOLD]The Aztecs[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The Aztec unique power enables them to acquire slave units by winning battles; regardless of the losing unit there is a chance of acquiring a slave unit. Aztec slaves also have the additional abilities of acting as workers and can be sacrificed in their cities, as a way to temporarily increase happiness there.

TEXT.English:
[H1]Stability Influence Factors[\H1] [NEWLINE][BOLD]EXPANSION[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Overextension[\BOLD] Overextension is the main factor of expansion stability. It depends on two scores: [ICON_BULLET]core population score [ICON_BULLET]periphery population score [NEWLINE]Without taking modifiers into account, they are just the population in your core and the population outside of your core, respectively. As long as your periphery population score is below your core population score, everything is fine. Once the periphery score exceeds 100% of the core population score, you will receive an expansion stability penalty according to a formula which I will explain later. The scores are affected by a number of modifiers and therefore aren't only based on city population. [NEWLINE]The [BOLD]core population score[\BOLD] is multiplied by your current era plus one. Since the modifier is era-based, your ability to support a large periphery grows during the game. [NEWLINE]The [BOLD]periphery population score[\BOLD] for every city is based on many different factors. Since a lower periphery score is better for stability, negative modifiers are desired. +2 if the city is not on historical territory (so it makes sense to mainly control historical tiles) +1 if you are not the original owner of this city (unless you are running Totalitarianism or Warrior Code, or the city is under your control for more than 25 turns) +1 if you have less than 50% culture in this city +1 if you have less than 20% culture in this city (those two penalties are cumulative, for a total of +2 if you are below 20%. Culture counts double within their civilization's own cores. Persia is immune to culture-based penalties due to their UP) +2 when running City States (this civic is only meant for small civilizations) +1 if it is a historical overseas city an you are running Totalitarianism (to discourage Totalitarianism for maintaining colonial empires) -1 if the city has a Courthouse -1 if the city has a Jail -1 if it is an overseas city and you are running Mercantilism -1 if it is an overseas city and you are Portugal (their UP) [NEWLINE]The expansion penalty can be at most -25, and grows faster right after the periphery score exceeds the core score than later on. This allows a diminishing yet growing effect of expansion stability that allows playing Domination games without making expansion stability irrelevant in more historical games. [NEWLINE]Between stability checks, the overextension penalty can only increase by at most 5 negative points. For instance, if you had a penalty of 0 in the last check and the calculation results in -10, you will still only get a penalty of -5 until the next check. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Razing[\BOLD] Razing cities is the other contributing factor to expansion stability. The score here is very straightforward. You get a -10 stability penalty for every city you have razed. This penalty decays by 2 points every 5 turns. This penalty is global, that means if you accrue -20 raze stability from razing two cities, it still decays by 2 points every 5 turns, instead of by 4. The exception to this rule are smaller cities. If the city has a population of less than 5, the penalty is -2 * [city population] instead. This exception does not apply to another civilizations capital, which always gives a -10 penalty when razed. [NEWLINE][BOLD]ECONOMY[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Economic Growth[\BOLD] The economic growth score is updated every third turn, in which the total amount of commerce produced is compared to the amount from three turns earlier. Has it grown by more than 5%, the score increases, has it shrunk by more than 5%, it decreases. Otherwise the score slowly moves towards 0 again. At every stability check the score is directly applied to the economy stability. Some of your civics influence your economic growth stability: [ICON_BULLET]you receive extra points during economic growth when running Free Market [ICON_BULLET]you receive no penalties during economic stagnation when running Environmentalism [ICON_BULLET]you receive less penalties during economic decline when running Public Welfare [NEWLINE][BOLD]Trade[\BOLD] Your cities have trade routes to other cities generating commerce (exports). Other cities have trade routes to your cities also generating commerce (imports). For all civilizations, their total trade volume is calculated, which usually is the sum of exports and imports, but for Mercantilist civs it is twice their export volume instead. The trade volume is divided by your number of cities, then subtracted a modifier that increases with your era. Effectively, you can achieve a positive score by increasing the trade yield in your cities and securing trade routes with foreign cities. The trade stability is capped at +10 and -10 respectively. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Economic Systems[\BOLD] Civilizations running Mercantilism receive a -2 penalty for having open borders with a civilization with a higher commerce output. Civilizations running Central Planning receive a -2 penalty for having open borders with a civilization that runs Free Market. [NEWLINE][BOLD]DOMESTIC[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Happiness[\BOLD] Happiness stability works similar to economic growth stability in that it is accumulating every third turn depending on the situation of your civilization. To that end, the happy and unhappy cities in a civilization are counted based on the following criteria: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Happy city:[\BOLD] currently celebrates the "We Love the King" day OR its happiness exceeds its unhappiness by at least a quarter of your empire's average city size and it has at least the average city size of your empire [BOLD]Unhappy city:[\BOLD] the city has more unhappiness than happiness OR the extra unhappiness (from all factors except population) exceeds a fifth of the city's population [NEWLINE]Note that it is possible for a city to not fulfill either of these criteria, in which case it doesn't count at all for the purposes of happiness stability. A city can also both fulfill the criteria for being happy and unhappy, in which case it counts as happy. Your happiness stability grows every third turn if you have more happy than unhappy cities, and declines if you have more unhappy than happy cities. This factor cannot exceed -10 or 10, respectively. If the amount of happy and unhappy cities is exactly the same, the value slowly approaches 0 again. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Religion[\BOLD] For religions, two or three percentages are calculated: [ICON_BULLET]the percentage of cities that have your state religion (believer ratio) [ICON_BULLET]the percentage of cities that have at least one non-state religion (heathen ratio) [ICON_BULLET]if you are running Theocracy, the percentage of cities that have ONLY your state religion [NEWLINE]Some non-state religions are ignored for the purposes of the second and third ratios ("tolerance"). [ICON_BULLET]civs with Secularism tolerate all non-state religions [ICON_BULLET]Mughals tolerate all non-state religions because of their UP [ICON_BULLET]Hinduism and Buddhism tolerate each other [ICON_BULLET]Confucianism and Taoism tolerate each other [NEWLINE][BOLD]Heathen ratio:[\BOLD] You incur neither penalties nor bonuses if your ratio is 30%. Otherwise, you receive -1 stability for every 10% over 30% and +1 stability for every 10% below 30%. [BOLD]Believer ratio:[\BOLD] You incur neither penalties nor bonuses if your ratio is 75%. Otherwise, you receive -1 stability for every 5% below 75% (up to a maximum of -10) and +1 stability for every 5% over 75%. [BOLD]Theocracy bonus:[\BOLD] if you are running Theocracy, you also receive +1 stability for every 20% of your cities that only have your state religion. [NEWLINE]Note that while the other factors require you to have a state religion, the religion stability from the heathen ratio also applies when you don't have a state religion. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Civics[\BOLD] Civics stability comes either from running a certain combination of civics or from running specific civics in a certain era or after discovering a certain technology.
Totalitarianism + State Party: +5 Totalitarianism + Despotism: +3 Totalitarianism + Ideology: +3 Totalitarianism + Central Planning: +3 Totalitarianism + any religious civic except Secularism: -5 Totalitarianism + Constitution: -5
Central Planning + Egalitarianism: +2 Central Planning + State Party: +2 Central Planning + Centralism: +2
Egalitarianism + Democracy: +2 Egalitarianism + Consitution: +2 Egalitarianism + any religious civic except Tolerance and Secularism: -3
Individualism + Republic or Democracy: +2 Individualism + Free Enterprise: +3 Individualism + Central Planning: -5 Individualism + Regulated Trade or Public Welfare: -2 Individualism + Tolerance: +2
Theocracy + Individualism or Egalitarianism: -3
Deification + Republic: -3 Deification + Democracy: -3 Deification + Redistribution until the Medieval era: +2 Deification + Slavery until the Medieval era: +2
Vassalage + Individualism or Egalitarianism: -5 Vassalage + Free Enterprise or Central Planning or Public Welfare: -3 Vassalage + Tributaries: +5 Vassalage + Monarchy in the Medieval era: +2 Vassalage + Manorialism in the Medieval era: -3
Republic + Citizenship: +2 Republic + Vassalage: -3 Republic + Merchant Trade: +2
Centralism + Democracy: -5 Centralism + Regulated Trade: +3 Centralism + Clergy: +2 Centralism + Monarchy in the Renaissance: +2
Despotism + Slavery: +2 Despotism + Nationhood: +3
Caste System + Citizenship: -4 Caste System + Clergy: +2 Caste System + Secularism: -3
Multilateralism + Despotism: -3 Multilateralism + Totalitarianism: -3 Multilateralism + Egalitarianism: +2 Multilateralism + Theocracy: -3
Monarchy + Clergy or Monasticism: +2
Elective + Centralism: -5
Constitution + Democracy: +2
Ideology + any religious civic except Tolerance and Secularism: -3
Regulated Trade + Manoralism: +2 Regulated Trade + Meritocracy: +3
Isolationism + Merchant Trade or Free Enterprise: -4 Isolationism + Regulated tRade or Central Planning: +3
Vassalage in the Middle Ages: +2 Vassalage in the Industrial Era or later: -5
Deification in the Classical Era or earlier: +2 Deification in after the Classical Era: -2 per era after the Classical Era
Republic in the Classical Era or earlier: +2 Republic in the Industrial Era or later: -5
Not running any civic out of Republic, Democracy, Ideology or Constitution after the discovery of Representation: -5
Slavery or Manorialism or Caste System after the discovery of Civil Rights: -5
Reciprocity or Redistribution or Merchant Trade after the discovery of Economics: -5
Conquest or Tributaries after the discovery of Nationalism: -5
Animism or Deification after the discovery of Theology: -5
Caste System with Hindu state religion: +3
Meritocracy with Confucian state religion: +3
Slavery with Christian or Zoroastrian state religion: -3
Slavery with Muslim state religion: +2
Monasticism with Buddhist state religion: +2 [NEWLINE][BOLD]FOREIGN[\BOLD] [NEWLINE]A couple of factors contribute to your foreign stability rating:
For every neighboring collapsing civ that you have open borders with: -3
For every collapsing vassal: -5 For every unstable vassal: -2 For every solid vassal: +3 For every vassal when running Vassalage: +2
For every defensive pact with a higher ranked civilization: +5 For every defensive pact with another civilization while running Multilateralism: +3
For every open borders treaty with a civ with your state religion: +1 For every open borders treaty with a civ with a different state religion: +2 For every second civilization you can contact: -1
Being the worst enemy of a higher ranked civilization: -4
For every neighbor you are at war with while running Autocracy: +2 For every civilization you are at war with while running Multilateralism: -2 For every civilization with different state religion you are at war with while running Fanaticism: +3 For every civilization with the same state religion you are at war with while running Fanaticism: -2 [NEWLINE][BOLD]MILITARY[\BOLD] [NEWLINE]All military scores are calculated for each war your civilization is in. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Conquest Stability[\BOLD] This factor depends on the number of cities you have conquered from this civ compared to those you have lost to it. Cities are worth more if the owner has less of them, i.e. losing a city has a larger impact if you don't have a lot of them in the first place. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Battle Stability[\BOLD] Similar to conquest stability, the battles you have won are compared to the battles you have lost. In either case, a battle is "worth" as much as the defeated unit's power rating. How much battle stability you get or lose depends on your overall military strength - the stronger you are, the less of an impact a singular battle has in either way. Battle stability decays while a war lasts. [NEWLINE][BOLD]War Weariness Stability[\BOLD] Your war weariness is compared to your enemy's. If it is larger, you receive a penalty proportional to the difference. This penalty also decays while the war lasts. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Barbarian Losses Stability[\BOLD] You receive a -1 stability penalty for every battle you lose against a barbarian unit. This penalty also decays over time.

Monasticism with Buddhist state religion: +2 [NEWLINE][BOLD]FOREIGN[\BOLD] [NEWLINE]A couple of factors contribute to your foreign stability rating:
For every neighboring collapsing civ that you have open borders with: -3
For every collapsing vassal: -5 For every unstable vassal: -2 For every solid vassal: +3 For every vassal when running Vassalage: +2
For every defensive pact with a higher ranked civilization: +5 For every defensive pact with another civilization while running Multilateralism: +3
For every open borders treaty with a civ with your state religion: +1 For every open borders treaty with a civ with a different state religion: +2 For every second civilization you can contact: -1
Being the worst enemy of a higher ranked civilization: -4
For every neighbor you are at war with while running Autocracy: +2 For every civilization you are at war with while running Multilateralism: -2 For every civilization with different state religion you are at war with while running Fanaticism: +3 For every civilization with the same state religion you are at war with while running Fanaticism: -2 [NEWLINE][BOLD]MILITARY[\BOLD] [NEWLINE]All military scores are calculated for each war your civilization is in. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Conquest Stability[\BOLD] This factor depends on the number of cities you have conquered from this civ compared to those you have lost to it. Cities are worth more if the owner has less of them, i.e. losing a city has a larger impact if you don't have a lot of them in the first place. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Battle Stability[\BOLD] Similar to conquest stability, the battles you have won are compared to the battles you have lost. In either case, a battle is "worth" as much as the defeated unit's power rating. How much battle stability you get or lose depends on your overall military strength - the stronger you are, the less of an impact a singular battle has in either way. Battle stability decays while a war lasts. [NEWLINE][BOLD]War Weariness Stability[\BOLD] Your war weariness is compared to your enemy's. If it is larger, you receive a penalty proportional to the difference. This penalty also decays while the war lasts. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Barbarian Losses Stability[\BOLD] You receive a -1 stability penalty for every battle you lose against a barbarian unit. This penalty also decays over time.

TEXT.English: [H1]Stability[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The stability system from Rhye's and Fall has been completely replaced in Dawn of Civilization, which features a completely redesigned stability mechanic. The main principles of the new system are that no permanent stability score is stored. Instead every civilization has a stability level, ranging from the familiar Collapsing to Solid. This level can change during a stability check, which can be triggered by a number of events. During the check a stability score is calculated based on a great variety of factors. Depending on the score, the stability level can either remain constant, increase or drop. A stability drop can also cause a crisis. Crises can have different negative effects on your empire. The type of the effects depends on the category in which your stability scored the lowest, while the severity of the crisis is determined by your stability level. A crisis on Collapsing leads to a complete collapse and the elimination of a civilization. After a stability check is over, the calculated score will be discarded. This new system that does not rely on persistent scores and only calculates them during stability checks significantly improves the performance of the stability mechanic and also results in more intuitive outcomes because only the current situation in your civilization matters. [H2]Stability Levels[\H2]Stability levels represent the overall stability of your empire. Stability levels are persistent and should not be confused with the stability score which is calculated on stability checks according to the rules described below, and then discarded. There are five stability levels from best to worst: [ICON_BULLET]Solid [ICON_BULLET]Stable [ICON_BULLET]Shaky [ICON_BULLET]Unstable [ICON_BULLET]Collapsing Your stability level can change during a stability check. They also influence what happens when a stability check has a negative outcome. [H2]Stability Checks[\H2]A stability check is when your stability "matters". They don't happen periodically, but instead are triggered by a number of events: [ICON_BULLET]losing a city [ICON_BULLET]razing a city (human only) [ICON_BULLET]discovering a technology [ICON_BULLET]becoming a vassal [ICON_BULLET]acquiring a vassal (+) [ICON_BULLET]starting a war [ICON_BULLET]making peace (+) [ICON_BULLET]changing civics or state religion [ICON_BULLET]moving your capital [ICON_BULLET]building a wonder (+) [ICON_BULLET]starting a golden age (+) [ICON_BULLET]receiving a great person (+) [NEWLINE]Events marked with a (+) trigger positive stability checks. These checks cannot have negative consequences, which will be explained in more detail below. [NEWLINE]During a check, your stability score is calculated according to the rules described in the previous post. This score is compared to the stability threshold. Based on this comparison, the stability check can have three possible outcomes: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Positive:[\BOLD] The stability score exceeds the threshold by more than 10 points [BOLD]Neutral:[\BOLD] The stability score is equal to or greater than the threshold (but by not more than 10 points) [BOLD]Negative:[\BOLD] The stability score is less than the threshold [NEWLINE]The threshold itself depends on your situation. In particular, it depends on the current stability level: [ICON_BULLET]on solid: +20 [ICON_BULLET]on unstable: +10 [ICON_BULLET]on shaky: 0 [ICON_BULLET]on unstable: -10 [ICON_BULLET]on collapsing: -20 [NEWLINE]The varying threshold has the purpose of making sure that a civilization does not "fall through the levels" with a constant stability score in subsequent checks. So unless their score changes, every civilization will eventually arrive at a stability level that reflects it. [NEWLINE]The threshold is also lower later in the game to improve overall stability, and during golden ages to allow stability gains in these periods. The average stability of all other civilizations also influences the threshold to avoid a world of only unstable or only stable civs. [NEWLINE]The consequences of a stability check are as follows: [BOLD]Positive:[\BOLD] The stability level increases by one. [BOLD]Neutral:[\BOLD] Nothing happens. [BOLD]Negative:[\BOLD] The stability level decreases by one. If the previous stability level was shaky or lower, a crisis occurs. Civilizations on solid or stable cannot trigger crises. [NEWLINE]During a positive stability check (labeled with a (+) above), negative stability checks have no consequences. [NEWLINE]Human players receive an additional warning for negative outcomes of stability checks. In practice that means that they are immune against the first negative outcome of a stability check, and only subsequent negative outcomes will take effect. Instead, a warning will be displayed in the main event log. [NEWLINE]Civilizations that experience a crisis are also immune against stability checks of any kind for the next ten turns. [H2]Crises[\H2] A negative outcome of a stability check can trigger a crisis. The type of crisis depends on two factors: your [BOLD]stability level[\BOLD] and the stability category with the lowest value (the [BOLD]crisis type[\BOLD]).[NEWLINE]Negative outcomes on solid or stable don't trigger a crisis. [NEWLINE]A crisis on collapsing is also called a [BOLD]terminal crisis[\BOLD] and always leads to a complete collapse of the civilization, regardless of crisis type. AI civilizations are immune to collapses triggered by stability checks from declarations of war by the human player.[NEWLINE] Crises on shaky are [BOLD]moderate crises[\BOLD], while crises on unstable are [BOLD]severe crises[\BOLD]. Their effects depend on the crisis type, i.e. there are: [ICON_BULLET]territorial crises (expansion) [ICON_BULLET]economic crises (economy) [ICON_BULLET]domestic crises (domestic) [ICON_BULLET]diplomatic crises (foreign) [ICON_BULLET]military crises (military) [NEWLINE][BOLD]Territorial Crisis:[\BOLD] Moderate: a single city secedes from your empire. It is chosen according to your stability map, so if available it will be a city on ahistorical territory. Severe: "Collapse to core": if more than half of all non-core cities are ahistorical, all ahistorical cities will secede. Otherwise, all non-core cities will secede. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Economic Crisis:[\BOLD] Moderate: You lose gold equivalent to 50% of your research progress (sum of all techs which you have begun to research). If you do not have enough gold on treasury, the beakers invested in the techs will be subtracted directly. Severe: You lose gold equivalent to 100% of your research progress (see above). All your cottages downgrade one level. You lose all GP points in all cities. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Domestic Crisis:[\BOLD] Moderate: All unhappy cities will go into two turns of unrest. Severe: Two turns of anarchy. All unhappy cities secede. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Diplomatic Crisis[\BOLD] Moderate: Your relations with 2 civilizations will deteriorate. Severe: Your relations with 5 civilizations will deteriorate. All your vassals are set free. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Military Crisis[\BOLD] Moderate: The defense value of all cities with enemy claim is reduced to 0. Severe: Two turns of unrest in all cities with enemy claim. You cannot move all military units for one turn.

TEXT.English: [H1]Tile Stability Display[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]In Dawn of Civilization, the stability effect of a specific tile is displayed in the tooltip when you hover over it on the map. The stability categories of tiles are Core (cyan), Historical (light green), Contested (yellow), Foreign (orange) and Foreign Core (red). The colors associated with the categories match those of the stability maps released for RFC.[PARAGRAPH:2]The stability category of a tile influences your expansion stability in multiple ways, depending on the circumstances. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Core Area:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Cities in your core area contribute to your core population score [ICON_BULLET]You can collapse if you're completely pushed out of your core area [ICON_BULLET]You only need 20% culture to maintain control over a tile in your core [NEWLINE][BOLD]Historical Area:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]No stability penalties for controlling cities [NEWLINE][BOLD]Contested Area:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]No stability penalties for controlling cities [ICON_BULLET]Risk of respawn of another civilization [ICON_BULLET]The civilization native to this area only needs 20% culture to maintain control over this tile [ICON_BULLET]It is harder to build up culture here, which can lead to stability penalties [NEWLINE][BOLD]Foreign Area:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Controlling cities here can hurt your expansion stability [NEWLINE][BOLD]Foreign Core Area:[\BOLD] [ICON_BULLET]Controlling cities here can hurt your expansion stability [ICON_BULLET]Risk of respawn of another civilization [ICON_BULLET]The civilization native to this area only needs 20% culture to maintain control over this tile [ICON_BULLET]It is harder to build up culture here, which can lead to stability penalties

TEXT.English: [H1]Trading Companies[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]If you are either Portugal, Spain, France, England or the Netherlands, building the Trading Company triggers an event that gives you the opportunity to expand your colonial empire into South Asia. The event selects a number of target cities and gives you the choice to either attempt to acquire them by investing money or raising an army. In case of the former, the owning civ can decline your gold offer, which means the gold is lost. In case of the latter, you lose population and happiness in your capital (similar to drafting), armies appear close to the target cities and you enter war with their owners. If the target areas are empty, you get a settler there instead. AI civilizations get the same opportunity by discovering Astronomy and Gunpowder (Portugal and Spain) or Economics and Rifling (France, England and Netherlands), without building a Trading Company. [NEWLINE]The target areas of each civilization are as follows: [BOLD]Portugal:[\BOLD] three (five for the AI) cities out of Sao Salvador, Quelimane, Muscat, Goa, Cochin, Malacca and Canton [BOLD]Spain:[\BOLD] always Manila [BOLD]France:[\BOLD] one city in South India [BOLD]England:[\BOLD] three cities in India [BOLD]Netherlands:[\BOLD] three cities in Indonesia

TEXT.English: [H1]Unique Powers and Historical Victories[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]There are no leader traits in Rhye's and Fall of Civilization. They were removed and replaced with a system of Unique Powers: each civilization has one unique ability according to its historical role. Given the different start years, each civilization have its own modifiers (which rendered leader traits useless). Their effect are summarized in the civ selection screen, at the beginning of the game, with general parameters rated 1 to 5 stars.[PARAGRAPH:2]Each Civilization can achieve a "Historical Victory" fulfilling 3 goals that differ from civ to civ and match their own historical background or just what they were trying to achieve. This way even a civilization with a weaker starting situation such as Aztecs has a chance of success. When 2 goals out of 3 are achieved, a "Triumphal Arch" is automatically built in player's capital, triggering a Golden Age.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization adds historical victories for religions, which are called Unique Religious Victories (URVs). Civilizations can complete the URV of their state religion, while civilizations without access to a state religion have the opportunity to win by completing the Polytheism (when running Pantheon) or Secularism URV. The Religious Victory also differs from the Historical Victory that all goal conditions have to be fulfilled at the same time to win, and that no reward for completing two goals is available. Also, many goals are global and take the situation of all civilizations with that state religion into account.

TEXT.English: [H1]Great People[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Time and again through history, there have arisen men and women who have profoundly changed the world around them - artists, scientists, prophets and others whose genius sets them head and shoulders above the rest. In Civilization IV, such visionaries are called "Great People."[PARAGRAPH:2]There are five different kinds of great people in the game: Great Prophets, Great Merchants, Great Artists, Great Scientists, and Great Engineers. Each has a special ability.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Generating Great People[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Great people are generated in cities. Each city generates a separate pool of "great people points" - when the city has earned enough points, it will generate a great person. The cost of generating a great person escalates throughout the game: the first great person costs 100 great people points, the second costs 200, and so forth. (The number of points needed to produce a great person is different on the Quick and Epic game speeds.)[PARAGRAPH:2]The first civilization to discover certain technologies will also receive a free great person in their capital city. For example, the first civ to discover [LINK=TECH_MUSIC]Music[\LINK] receives a Great Artist.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Great People Points[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A city generates great people points in a number of ways: by constructing [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK], by assigning citizens to be specialists, and by choosing certain [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wonders:[\BOLD] A wonder will generate a certain number of great people points each turn. Further, some wonders can increase a city's (or entire civilization's!) great people point generation significantly (see the [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Parthenon[\LINK] for an example). Like specialists (see next), some wonders increase the chances of generating a specific type of great person in their city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Specialists:[\BOLD] In each [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City[\LINK] you can assign citizens to be "specialists." Each specialist provides some kind of production bonus to its city; in addition, most generate great people points (the citizen specialist being the sole exception). Further, the kinds of specialists you have in a city determine which great people you generate: if all of your specialists in a city are priests, when that city generates a great person, he or she will be a great prophet. If half the specialists are merchants and the other half artists, you'll have a fifty-fifty chance of generating a great artist or great merchant.Moving the mouse over the great person points bar will display the percentage of getting each type of great person.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Civics:[\BOLD] Some [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK] increase the speed at which you generate great people.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Great People Characterists[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]As mentioned above, there are five types of great people. Each type has its own special abilities, but they all share some characteristics:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Can Discover New Technologies:[\BOLD] You can expend a great person to discover a new technology. Typically this technology will be in the great person's area of expertise (prophets will usually discover religious technologies and so on), but not always. Once all of the relatively inexpensive technologies have been discovered, the great person may not be able to entirely discover a new tech, but he or she can dramatically decrease the time it takes you to discover it.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Golden Ages:[\BOLD] You can expend two or more great people to start a [LINK=CONCEPT_GOLDEN_AGE]"Golden Age"[\LINK]; see that section for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Settling in Cities:[\BOLD] All great persons also have the ability to settle in a city as a sort of "super-specialist". Settling a great person in a city will add certain bonuses to that city each turn; for example, a Great Prophet will add 2 production and 5 gold to the city it settles in. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Special Abilities[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] In addition to their common abilities, each great person type has other unique abilities.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Artists:[\BOLD] Great Artists can create great works of art in a city; this immediately gives that city additional [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Culture[\LINK] points (from 2,000 to 6,000, depending upon game speed). This is extremely useful if a city is under cultural threat from a neighbor (or you wish to culturally attack those cities!). Great Artists can also "permanently settle" in a city, providing a continuing large cultural and small research boost to the city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Engineers:[\BOLD] Great Engineers can "hurry" a city's production, greatly speeding up the creation of whatever the city is presently constructing. Most early wonders can be completed in a single turn by Great Engineers, and later ones can be sped up dramatically. Great Engineers can permanently settle in a city, providing a continuing large production and small research boost to that city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Merchants:[\BOLD] A Great Merchant can conduct a "trade mission" which will immediately give you a whole bunch of gold. To conduct a trade mission, first move the merchant to a wealthy and powerful city as far away from your cities as possible. When the merchant reaches the target city you'll be able to conduct the mission; trade missions can ONLY be carried out in foreign cities. The value of the mission increases the further away and wealthier the target city is. Great Merchants can also settle permanently in a city, providing a continuing large commerce and small food boost to the city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Prophet:[\BOLD] Great Prophets can create religious shrines - the [LINK=BUILDING_PROTESTANT_SHRINE]Temple of Solomon[\LINK] and the [LINK=BUILDING_CONFUCIAN_SHRINE]Kong Miao[\LINK], for example. However, Great Prophets can create religious shrines ONLY in a city where a religion was founded. Using a Great Prophet is the only way to build a religion's shrine. Great Prophets can also settle in a city, providing a continuing large commerce and small production boost to that city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Scientist:[\BOLD] Great Scientists can construct an [LINK=BUILDING_ACADEMY]Academy[\LINK], a building which greatly boots a city's scientific research as well as its culture. Great Scientists can also settle permanently in a city, providing a large research and small production boost to the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.Chinese: [H1]Great People[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Time and again through history, there have arisen men and women who have profoundly changed the world around them - artists, scientists, prophets and others whose genius sets them head and shoulders above the rest. In Civilization IV, such visionaries are called "Great People."[PARAGRAPH:2]There are five different kinds of great people in the game: Great Prophets, Great Merchants, Great Artists, Great Scientists, and Great Engineers. Each has a special ability.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Generating Great People[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Great people are generated in cities. Each city generates a separate pool of "great people points" - when the city has earned enough points, it will generate a great person. The cost of generating a great person escalates throughout the game: the first great person costs 100 great people points, the second costs 200, and so forth. (The number of points needed to produce a great person is different on the Quick and Epic game speeds.)[PARAGRAPH:2]The first civilization to discover certain technologies will also receive a free great person in their capital city. For example, the first civ to discover [LINK=TECH_MUSIC]Music[\LINK] receives a Great Artist.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Great People Points[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A city generates great people points in a number of ways: by constructing [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK], by assigning citizens to be specialists, and by choosing certain [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wonders:[\BOLD] A wonder will generate a certain number of great people points each turn. Further, some wonders can increase a city's (or entire civilization's!) great people point generation significantly (see the [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Parthenon[\LINK] for an example). Like specialists (see next), some wonders increase the chances of generating a specific type of great person in their city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Specialists:[\BOLD] In each [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City[\LINK] you can assign citizens to be "specialists." Each specialist provides some kind of production bonus to its city; in addition, most generate great people points (the citizen specialist being the sole exception). Further, the kinds of specialists you have in a city determine which great people you generate: if all of your specialists in a city are priests, when that city generates a great person, he or she will be a great prophet. If half the specialists are merchants and the other half artists, you'll have a fifty-fifty chance of generating a great artist or great merchant.Moving the mouse over the great person points bar will display the percentage of getting each type of great person.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Civics:[\BOLD] Some [LINK=CONCEPT_CIVICS]Civics[\LINK] increase the speed at which you generate great people.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Great People Characterists[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]As mentioned above, there are five types of great people. Each type has its own special abilities, but they all share some characteristics:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Can Discover New Technologies:[\BOLD] You can expend a great person to discover a new technology. Typically this technology will be in the great person's area of expertise (prophets will usually discover religious technologies and so on), but not always. Once all of the relatively inexpensive technologies have been discovered, the great person may not be able to entirely discover a new tech, but he or she can dramatically decrease the time it takes you to discover it.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Golden Ages:[\BOLD] You can expend two or more great people to start a [LINK=CONCEPT_GOLDEN_AGE]"Golden Age"[\LINK]; see that section for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Settling in Cities:[\BOLD] All great persons also have the ability to settle in a city as a sort of "super-specialist". Settling a great person in a city will add certain bonuses to that city each turn; for example, a Great Prophet will add 2 production and 5 gold to the city it settles in. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Special Abilities[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2] In addition to their common abilities, each great person type has other unique abilities.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Artists:[\BOLD] Great Artists can create great works of art in a city; this immediately gives that city additional [LINK=CONCEPT_CULTURE]Culture[\LINK] points (from 2,000 to 6,000, depending upon game speed). This is extremely useful if a city is under cultural threat from a neighbor (or you wish to culturally attack those cities!). Great Artists can also "permanently settle" in a city, providing a continuing large cultural and small research boost to the city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Engineers:[\BOLD] Great Engineers can "hurry" a city's production, greatly speeding up the creation of whatever the city is presently constructing. Most early wonders can be completed in a single turn by Great Engineers, and later ones can be sped up dramatically. Great Engineers can permanently settle in a city, providing a continuing large production and small research boost to that city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Merchants:[\BOLD] A Great Merchant can conduct a "trade mission" which will immediately give you a whole bunch of gold. To conduct a trade mission, first move the merchant to a wealthy and powerful city as far away from your cities as possible. When the merchant reaches the target city you'll be able to conduct the mission; trade missions can ONLY be carried out in foreign cities. The value of the mission increases the further away and wealthier the target city is. Great Merchants can also settle permanently in a city, providing a continuing large commerce and small food boost to the city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Prophet:[\BOLD] Great Prophets can create religious shrines - the [LINK=BUILDING_PROTESTANT_SHRINE]Temple of Solomon[\LINK] and the [LINK=BUILDING_CONFUCIAN_SHRINE]Kong Miao[\LINK], for example. However, Great Prophets can create religious shrines ONLY in a city where a religion was founded. Using a Great Prophet is the only way to build a religion's shrine. Great Prophets can also settle in a city, providing a continuing large commerce and small production boost to that city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Great Scientist:[\BOLD] Great Scientists can construct an [LINK=BUILDING_ACADEMY]Academy[\LINK], a building which greatly boots a city's scientific research as well as its culture. Great Scientists can also settle permanently in a city, providing a large research and small production boost to the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.English: [H1]Specialists[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]When a [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City[\LINK] is first founded, all of its citizens are bound in the various requirements of day-to-day survival: hunting, fishing, tilling the land, and so forth. This may continue for some time, but eventually the city may grow large and prosperous enough that it can afford to dedicate some of its population to more rewarding pursuits. In Civilization IV, these more useful citizens are called "Specialists."[PARAGRAPH:2]There are six categories of specialists in Civilization IV: Engineer, Merchant, Scientist, Artist, Priest, and the default "Citizen" specialist. Each provides a city certain benefits.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Requirements for Employing Specialists[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]At the start of the game, you may only create one kind of specialist: the Citizen, who is the least useful of all of them. Each of the other specialist types requires certain [LINK=CONCEPT_BUILDINGS]Buildings[\LINK] or [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK] to be created. Further, each building or wonder will allow a limited number of specialists. For example, building a Temple allows you to create one (and only one) Priest in its city. But if you subsequently build a Cathedral there, you can create an additional two priests, for a total of three.[PARAGRAPH:2]The [LINK=CIVIC_CASTE_SYSTEM]Caste System[\LINK] civic allows you to create as many Merchant, Scientist, and Artist specialists in a city as you desire, regardless of whether or not you have the buildings that would normally be needed to create them. Be aware, however, that there is no way to get around the limitation on the number of Engineers and Priests that a city can support; you must have either the buildings or wonders necessary to create these specialists.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Turning City Population into Specialists[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When a city increases its population, it first seeks to employ that new population working the land around the city. (See [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]Cities[\LINK].) If any land spaces are yet unworked, the city puts the new civilian on the space it thinks will do the most good. A city can work up to 20 spaces - fewer if the city contains deserts or peaks in its [LINK=CONCEPT_CITIES]City Radius[\LINK]. If you turn one of those working populations into a specialist, it no longer works the land. It still must eat, however, so the city's remaining working population must provide enough food for everybody. If not, the city will begin to starve. As a general rule, therefore, cities with more food will be able to create more specialists; cities that are food-poor will need all of their citizens to work the land just to prevent starvation.[PARAGRAPH:2]Once a city is working all available land, it automatically turns any additional population into specialists (keep in mind this usually will not take place until very late in the game!). It attempts to create the most useful specialist available; if no other slots are open, it creates a citizen specialist. You can also manually create specialists yourself by removing citizens from working the land (see below). When a city is about to grow past the level of [LINK=CONCEPT_HAPPINESS]Happiness[\LINK] that it can support, it is often a good idea to turn some of the population into specialists and halt growth rather than let the city increase in size and produce useless unhappy citizens.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Specialists and Great People[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]In addition to their other functions described below, specialists increase a city's generation of "Great People Points" by +3 each. Specialists also help determine what kind of great person the city will generate. See [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great People[\LINK] for more details.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]How to Create a Specialist[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]You can create a specialist on the city screen. The six types are visible on the right-hand edge of the screen. If a specialist type is grayed-out, you cannot build one. If a specialist is in full color, however, you can: click on the plus (+) sign next to the specialist you want to create. If you want to remove a specialist, click on the minus (-) sign. Creating a specialist removes one of your population points from working a tile in the City Radius.[PARAGRAPH:2]In order to manually select which tile to remove, first click on the tile that you want removed (the white circle around it should disappear). This creates a Citizen specialist. Then click on the plus (+) sign next to the specialist you want to employ, and the Citizen specialist will be replaced with the one you desire.[PARAGRAPH:2]Note that some [LINK=CONCEPT_WONDERS]Wonders[\LINK] automatically give you one or more specialists of a specific type; you can't remove or repurpose them at all. Some wonders and civics may also provide you with a free specialist in each city; in this case, you can choose which specialist to employ in each city, but cannot remove the specialist altogether.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Specialist Types[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Engineer[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Engineers increase a city's production by +2. They increase the city's great person generation rate by +3. They increase the chance that the city will generate a Great Engineer. [LINK=BUILDING_FORGE]Forges[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_FACTORY]Factories[\LINK], and similar industrial buildings are needed to create Engineers.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Merchant[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Merchants increase gold by +3. They increase the city's great person generation rate by +3. They increase the chance that the city will generate a Great Merchant. [LINK=BUILDING_MARKET]Markets[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_BANK]Banks[\LINK], and similar commercial buildings are needed to create Merchants.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Scientist[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Scientists increase a city's research rate by +3. They increase the city's great person generation rate by +3. They increase the chance that the city will generate a Great Scientist. [LINK=BUILDING_LIBRARY]Libraries[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_UNIVERSITY]Universities[\LINK], and similar research institutions are needed to create Scientists.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Artist[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Artists increase a city's research rate by +1, and its culture by +4. They increase the city's great person generation rate by +3. They increase the chance that the city will generate a Great Artist. [LINK=BUILDING_THEATRE]Theatres[\LINK] and other centers of the arts are needed to create Artists.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Priest[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Priests increase a city's commerce and production by +1 each. They increase the city's great person generation rate by +3. They increase the chance that the city will generate a Great Prophet. Temples, Cathedrals, and other religious buildings are needed to create Priests.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Citizen[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Citizens increase a city's production by +1. They do not provide great person generation points, nor do they affect what kind of great person the city generates. Citizens require the construction of no buildings or wonders, and an unlimited number can always be employed. However, it is rarely worthwhile to create large numbers of Citizen specialists![PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Wonders and Civics[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Many wonders and civics can increase the power of specialists even further, with a variety of different effects.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Increased Great Person Points[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Several different wonders and civics increase the rate at which specialists create Great People. The [LINK=BUILDING_PARTHENON]Parthenon[\LINK] wonder increases the production of great person points by 50%% in all cities, and the [LINK=BUILDING_TRIUMPHAL_ARCH]National Epic[\LINK] national wonder increases the rate by 100%% in the city in which it is built. The [LINK=CIVIC_PACIFISM]Pacifism[\LINK] civic also increases great person generation by 100%% in all cities.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Other Effects[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Other effects include increasing the output of the specialists themselves. For example, the [LINK=BUILDING_WAT_PREAH_PISNULOK]Angkor Wat[\LINK] wonder adds +1 production to all Priest specialists, and the [LINK=BUILDING_SISTINE_CHAPEL]Sistine Chapel[\LINK] adds +2 culture to all specialists. The [LINK=CIVIC_REPRESENTATION]Representation[\LINK] civic also adds +3 research to all specialists. Since all of these effects are cumulative, specialists can become very powerful if enough attention is paid to them.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.English: [H1]Spies[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Spies are special "invisible" units which can sneak around the map and have a variety of special abilities. Spies also function defensively by increasing the odds of an enemy spy being exposed if it performs a mission in a nearby tiles.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Constructing Spies[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Spies may be built only in a city with the [LINK=BUILDING_SECRET_SERVICE]Scotland Yard[\LINK] national wonder.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Invisible[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Spy units are invisible. They cannot be seen, attacked, or otherwise interacted with.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Movement[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Spies move like other units, except that they do not cause an automatic declaration of war when crossing foreign [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Borders[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Spy Missions[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Spies may perform a variety of missions, some of which are automatically fatal and others of which contain a chance of destruction. Spies can perform these missions anywhere on the map, including in territory belonging to allies or to civilizations you are at war with.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Exploration[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Being invisible, spies can move through neutral, friendly and enemy territory without risk.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Investigate City[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Upon entering a foreign city, a spy may look at it's City Screen and thus know important things, like what defenses the city contains, what it is currently building, and so forth.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Destroy Production[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]A spy performs this in a city. If successful, the spy survives and the city loses half of the production points towards whatever it is currently producing. For example, this can be quite devastating if the city is just a couple of turns from completing construction of a wonder. If the mission is unsuccessful, no production is lost and the spy is destroyed.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Sabotage Improvement[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This is performed on any space containing an [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Improvement[\LINK]. If successful, the improvement is destroyed and the spy survives. If unsuccessful, the spy is destroyed and the improvement survives.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Steal Plans[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This mission has a much higher chance of success in one of a civilization's "centers of government" - a city containing the [LINK=BUILDING_PALACE]Palace[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_ADMINISTRATIVE_CENTER]Forbidden Palace[\LINK] or [LINK=BUILDING_VERSAILLES]Versailles[\LINK] wonder. If successful, the spy survives and you get to see everything that is visible to the foreign civilization. This includes everything in its territory or within sight of its units and borders. If unsuccessful, the spy dies and you don't get to see anything.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Determining Success or Failure of a Spy Mission[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]The odds of success or failure of a spy's mission depend upon the number of units the other player has in the space the mission takes place. If a space is unoccupied, the chances of success are quite high. The chances of detection and failure increase with each unit in the target space. Further, nearby enemy spies significantly increase the chances of being caught.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Diplomatic Effects of Missions[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]If a mission is successful, the target civilization will not know who performed the mission; thus that civilization's opinion of you will not change (see [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomacy[\LINK]). If the mission is a failure, the target civilization will know exactly who is responsible for the outrage and will adjust its opinion of you appropriately. It is quite possible for a failed spy mission to cause the victim civilization to declare war on your civilization![PARAGRAPH:2]
