TEXT.English: [TAB]Although large mills and workshops were established in ancient China, Rome and the Middle East, the Venice Arsenal provides one of the first examples of a factory in the modern sense of the word. Founded in 1104 in Venice, Republic of Venice, several hundred years before the Industrial Revolution, it mass-produced ships on assembly lines using manufactured parts. The Venice Arsenal apparently produced nearly one ship every day and, at its height, employed 16,000 people.[PARAGRAPH:2]Many historians regard Matthew Boulton 's Soho Manufactory (established in 1761 in Birmingham) as the first modern factory. (Other claims might be made for John Lombe 's silk mill in Derby (1721), or Richard Arkwright 's Cromford Mill (1771) purpose built to fit the equipment it held and taking the material through the various manufacturing processes.) One historian, Jack Weatherford, contends that the first factory was in Potosa, for processing silver ingot slugs into coins, because there was so much silver being mined close by. See City and Factory Life for more background concerning factory conditions.[PARAGRAPH:2]British colonies in the late 18th century built factories simply as buildings where a large number of laborers gathered to perform hand labor, usually in textile production. This proved more efficient for administration and for the distribution of raw materials to individual laborers than earlier methods of manufacturing such as cottage industries or the putting-out system.[PARAGRAPH:2]Cotton mills used inventions such as the steam engine and the power loom to pioneer the industrial factory of the 19th century, where precision machine tools and replaceable parts allowed greater efficiency and less waste.[PARAGRAPH:2]Between 1820 and 1850, the non-mechanized factories supplanted the traditional artisan shops as the predominant form of manufacturing institution. Even though the theory on why and how the non-mechanized factories gradually replaced the small artisan shops is still ambiguous, what is apparent is that the larger-scale factories enjoyed technological gains and advance in efficiency over the small artisan shops. In fact, the larger scale forms of factory establishments were more favorable and advantageous over the small artisan shops in terms of competition for survival.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Pharmacists are allied health professionals who practice in pharmacy, the field of health sciences focusing on safe and effective medication use. The role of the pharmacist has shifted from the classical "lick, stick, and pour" dispensary role (that is, "lick & stick the labels, count & pour the pills"), to being an integrated member of the health care team directly involved in patient care. Pharmacists undergo university-level education to understand biochemical mechanisms of action of drugs, drug uses and therapeutic roles, side effects, potential interactions, and monitoring parameters. This is mated to education in anatomy, physiology, and pathophysiology. Professional interpretation and communication of this specialized knowledge to patients, physicians, and other health care providers are functions which pharmacists provide, and are central to the provision of safe and effective drug therapy.[PARAGRAPH:2]The most common pharmacist positions are that of a community pharmacist (also referred to as "retail pharmacist" or "dispensing chemist"), or a hospital pharmacist, where they instruct and counsel on the proper use and adverse effects of medically prescribed drugs and medicines. In most countries, the profession is subject to professional regulation. Depending on the legal scope of practice, pharmacists may contribute to prescribing (also referred to as "pharmacist prescriber") and administering certain medications (e.g. immunizations in some jurisdictions). Pharmacists may also practice in a variety of other settings, including industry, research, academia, military, and government.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Archaeological evidence for the Old Babylonian school system suggests that scribal education was small-scale and usually took place in private homes. School tablets have been found in private residences in many sites across Mesopotamia. Some houses, where particularly large numbers of school tablets were unearthed, have been interpreted by archaeologists as "school houses" or homes in which scribal education almost certainly took place. The best example of this is House F in the city of Nippur. Nearly one and a half thousand fragments of tablets were found at this house. They date to the 17th century BCE (short chronology) (the early part of Samsu-iluna's reign), and the majority of them were students' school exercises. Two other possible "school houses" are located at the site of Ur. The first is a house called No. 7 Quiet Street, where a smaller number of school texts was found in situ and date to the late 18th or early 17th century BCE (short chronology) (reigns of Rim-Sin II or as late as Samsu-iluna year 11). The second is a house called No. 1 Broad Street, where a larger number of school tablets was discovered. Some texts from No. 1 Broad Street may date to as late as Samsu-iluna year 11 (1674 BCE short chronology, 1738 middle chronology). Unfortunately, it is unclear whether this house is the school texts' original place of use. Another Old Babylonian home in which scribal training took place is the house of a man named Ur-Utu, located in the ancient city of Sippar-Amnanum.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The practice of communication by written documents carried by an intermediary from one person or place to another almost certainly dates back nearly to the invention of writing. However, development of formal postal systems occurred much later. The first documented use of an organized courier service for the diffusion of written documents is in Egypt, where Pharaohs used couriers for the diffusion of their decrees in the territory of the State (2400 BC).[PARAGRAPH:2]The first credible claim for the development of a real postal system comes from Ancient Persia but the point of invention remains in question. The best documented claim (Xenophon) attributes the invention to the Persian King Cyrus the Great (550 BC), while other writers credit his successor Darius I of Persia (521 BC). Other sources claim much earlier dates for an Assyrian postal system, with credit given to Hammurabi (1700 BC) and Sargon II (722 BC). Mail may not have been the primary mission of this postal service, however. The role of the system as an intelligence gathering apparatus is well documented, and the service was (later) called angariae, a term that in time turned to indicate a tax system. The Old Testament (Esther, VIII) makes mention of this system: Ahasuerus, king of Medes, used couriers for communicating his decisions.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Persian system worked on stations (called Chapar-Khaneh), where the message carrier (called Chapar) would ride to the next post, whereupon he would swap his horse with a fresh one, for maximum performance and delivery speed. Herodotus described the system in this way: "It is said that as many days as there are in the whole journey, so many are the men and horses that stand along the road, each horse and man at the interval of a day's journey; and these are stayed neither by snow nor rain nor heat nor darkness from accomplishing their appointed course with all speed".[PARAGRAPH:2]The economic growth and political stability under the Mauryan empire (322-185 BC) saw the development of impressive civil infrastructure in ancient India. The Mauryans developed early Indian mail service as well as public wells, rest houses and other facilities for the common public. Common chariots called Dagana were sometimes used as mail chariots in ancient India.[PARAGRAPH:2]In ancient times the kings, emperors, rulers, zamindars or the feudal lords protected their land through the intelligence services of specially trained police or military agencies and courier services to convey and obtain information through runners, messengers and even through pigeons. The chief of the secret service, known as the postmaster, maintained the lines of communication... The people used to send letters to their distant relatives through their friends or neighbors.[PARAGRAPH:2]Early stamps of India were watermarked with an elephant's head. [PARAGRAPH:2]In South India, the Wodeyar dynasty (1399 - 1947) of the Kingdom of Mysore used mail service for espionage purposes thereby acquiring knowledge related to matters that took place at great distances.[PARAGRAPH:2]By the end of the 18th century the postal system in India had reached impressive levels of efficiency. According to British national Thomas Broughton, the Maharaja of Jodhpur sent daily offerings of fresh flowers from his capital to Nathadvara (320 km) and they arrived in time for the first religious Darshan at sunrise. Later this system underwent complete modernization when the British Raj established its full control over India. The Post Office Act XVII of 1837 provided that the Governor-General of India in Council had the exclusive right of conveying letters by post for hire within the territories of the East India Company. On this basis the Indian Post Office was established on October 1, 1837.[PARAGRAPH:2]China enjoyed postal relay stations since the Han dynasty (206 BC-220 AD). The service was called cursus publicus and was provided with light carriages called rhedÃÂ¦ with fast horses. Another service for citizens was later added.[PARAGRAPH:2]Genghis Khan installed an empire-wide messenger and postal station system named ?rt?? within the Mongol Empire. TEXT.English: [TAB]A sewer is an artificial conduit (or pipe) or system of conduits used to carry and remove sewage (human liquid waste) and to provide drainage. In the 21st century developed world, sewers are usually pipelines that begin with connecting pipes from buildings to one or more levels of larger underground horizontal mains, which terminate at sewage treatment facilities. Vertical pipes, called manholes, connect the mains to the surface. Sewers are generally gravity powered, though pumps may be used if necessary. [PARAGRAPH:2]The earliest covered sewers uncovered by archaeologists are in the regularly planned cities of the Indus Valley Civilization. In ancient Rome, the Cloaca Maxima, considered a marvel of engineering, disgorged into the Tiber. In medieval European cities, small natural waterways used for carrying off wastewater were eventually covered over and functioned as sewers. London's River Fleet is such a system. Open drains along the center of some streets were known as 'kennels' (= canals, channels).

TEXT.English: [TAB]A chiefdom is a form of hierarchical political organization in non-industrial societies usually based on kinship, and in which formal leadership is monopolized by the legitimate senior members of select families or 'houses'. These elites form a political-ideological aristocracy relative to the general group.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Unlike traditional monarchies, where rule is hereditary and passed down the family line, under an elective system rulers are chosen by election. Elective systems differ from democracies in that the monarch is generally chosen for life and the right to vote is limited to a small groups of magnates or special members of the aristocracy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Elective systems were prominent in medieval central Europe. In the Holy Roman Empire, the elective system was codified over the centuries to a group of Prince Electors choosing the next Emperor. The Polish king was also elected, first by a small group of nobles, later by the entire noble class. Other European examples include early Scandinavian kings and the Doge of Venice. Outside of Europe, the Mansa of the Mali Empire and the Tlatoani of the Aztec Triple Alliance were selected and confirmed by a privileged council. The selection of the Mongol Great Khan could also be considered an elective monarchy.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A one-party state is a type of state in which one political party has the right to form the government, usually based on the existing constitution. All other parties are either outlawed or allowed to take only a limited and controlled participation in elections. One-party states explain themselves through various methods. Most often, proponents of a one-party state argue that the existence of separate parties runs counter to national unity. Others argue that the one party is the vanguard of the people, and therefore its right to rule cannot be legitimately questioned. The Soviet government argued that multiple parties represented the class struggle, which was absent in Soviet society, and so the Soviet Union only had one party: The Communist Party.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Most one-party states have been ruled either by parties following the ideology of MarxismâLeninism and international solidarity (such as the Soviet Union for most of its existence), or by parties following some type of nationalist or fascist ideology (such as Italy under Benito Mussolini), or by parties that came to power in the wake of independence from colonial rule. One-party systems often arise from decolonization because one party has had an overwhelmingly dominant role in liberation or in independence struggles.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Citizenship describes the legal codification of the relationship between a state and its people. Instead of being just being a subject at the whim of the power of their ruler, the status of citizen comes with certain rights and obligations towards the state. The prime example of citizenship was the Roman Republic. Initially, only inhabitants of Rome could be citizens, which came with access to the Roman legal system, protection from enslavement, and political participation. Over the course of Roman history citizenship was gradually expanded to other populations under Roman rule, which furthered their integration into Roman society.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The concept of citizenship continued during the Roman Empire and entered the Western legal tradition. During the Middle Ages, citizenship was replaced by serfdom as the dominant form of social relationship, however the practice continued in independent cities. Modern European states, and later almost all states in the world, conferred citizenship to all its peoples for essentially the same reason the Roman Republic did.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Meritocracy is a political philosophy holding that power should be vested in individuals almost exclusively based on ability and talent. Advancement in such a system is based on performance measured through examination and/or demonstrated achievement in the field where it is implemented. According to scholarly consensus, the earliest example of an administrative meritocracy, based on civil service examinations, dates back to Ancient China.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The concept originates, at least by the sixth century BC, when it was advocated by the Chinese philosopher Confucius, who "invented the notion that those who govern should do so because of merit, not of inherited status. This sets in motion the creation of the imperial examinations and bureaucracies open only to those who passed tests."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]As the Qin and Han dynasties developed a meritocratic system in order to maintain power over a large, sprawling empire, it became necessary for the government to maintain a complex network of officials. Prospective officials could come from a rural background and government positions were not restricted to the nobility. Rank was determined by merit, through the civil service examinations, and education became the key for social mobility. After the fall of the Han Dynasty, the nine-rank system was established during the Three Kingdoms period.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Centralism describes a form of political organisation where all administrative decisions are made or controlled by the central government situated in the capital. Centralism stands in contrast to more decentralised forms of government such as feudalism or federalism. Ancient China has long had a tradition of central government, where all decisions were carried out by a central bureaucracy loyal to the Emperor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]In Europe, feudalism meant that the monarch only had limited power over his domains, since it had to be carried out through noble vassals. In the early modern period, European monarchs sought to increase their power by centralising decisions to the royal court. Archetypal for this development was France under Louis XIV, where the nobility was forced to attend the court at Versailles, so the monarch was able to exert control over them. In consequence, the bureaucracy was expanded to implement royal policy across the country. Other European states quickly emulated the success of this French model.

TEXT.English: [TAB]For most of history, the legitimacy of the state was derived from personal interest. Early in history, these were the interests of its rulers themselves, later with the advent of democracy the interests of its people. Marxist philosophy first introduced the idea of the state as a tool to implement a particular ideology. Marxism and similar ideologies derived from it argued that the working class should first take control of the state and then establish socialism, with the eventual goal of abolishing the state altogether. This idea was later expanded upon the idea of an international revolution that socialist states were supposed to export to other nations, if necessary by force. However, Marxism was not the only state ideology. Fascist Italy and Nazi Germany likewise put ideology at the centre of their state's purpose and reason of existence. During the Cold War, many countries adopted a state ideology to become part of the sphere of influence of one of the superpowers, and imposing their ideology on other countries (if necessary by force) was one of the major ways the Cold War was fought.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A constitution is a set of fundamental principles or established precedents according to which a state or other organization is governed. These rules together make up, i.e. constitute, what the entity is. When these principles are written down into a single document or set of legal documents, those documents may be said to embody a written constitution; if they are written down in a single comprehensive document, it is said to embody a codified constitution. Some constitutions (such as the constitution of the United Kingdom) are uncodified, but written in numerous fundamental Acts of a legislature, court cases or treaties.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]What is sometimes called the "enlightened constitution" model was developed by philosophers of the Age of Enlightenment such as Thomas Hobbes, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, and John Locke. The model proposed that constitutional governments should be stable, adaptable, accountable, open and should represent the people (i.e., support democracy). The United States Constitution, ratified June 21, 1788, was influenced by the writings of Polybius, Locke, Montesquieu, and others. The document became a benchmark for republicanism and codified constitutions written thereafter.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A traditionalist society is based on oral traditions and long established ways of doing things. Its authority is difficult to question, since no modern figure can easily claim the right to change what was established by the ancestors. This can be a great weakness of the system when times change, but so long as the basic mechanisms of existence remain stable, the tradition-oriented culture gains a strong sense of its own values, and feels powerful ties to the legacy of its own ancestors. As society became more settled, existing customs grew formalized and expanded. Priests and scribes served as guardians of collective social memory by keeping track of longstanding precedents and rituals, often dating back centuries to quasi-legendary founding heroes. Rulers sought to empower themselves by following the rites and policies established by such traditions.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Manorialism was an essential element of feudal society. It was the organizing principle of rural economy that originated in the Roman villa system of the Late Roman Empire, and was widely practiced in medieval western and parts of central Europe. It was slowly replaced by the advent of a money-based market economy and new forms of agrarian contract. Manorialism was characterised by the vesting of legal and economic power in a Lord of the Manor, supported economically from his own direct landholding in a manor (sometimes called a fief), and from the obligatory contributions of a legally subject part of the peasant population under the jurisdiction of himself and his manorial court. These obligations could be payable in several ways, in labor (the French term corv¨¦e is conventionally applied), in kind, or, on rare occasions, in coin.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Individualism is the moral stance, political philosophy, ideology, or social outlook that emphasizes the moral worth of the individual. Individualists promote the exercise of one's goals and desires and so value independence and self-reliance and advocate that interests of the individual should achieve precedence over the state or a social group, while opposing external interference upon one's own interests by society or institutions such as the government.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Liberalism is the belief in the importance of individual freedom. This belief is widely accepted in the United States, Europe, Australia and other Western nations, and was recognized as an important value by many Western philosophers throughout history, in particular since the Enlightenment.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]Individualism is the moral stance, political philosophy, ideology, or social outlook that emphasizes the moral worth of the individual. Individualists promote the exercise of one's goals and desires and so value independence and self-reliance and advocate that interests of the individual should achieve precedence over the state or a social group, while opposing external interference upon one's own interests by society or institutions such as the government.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Liberalism is the belief in the importance of individual freedom. This belief is widely accepted in the United States, Europe, Australia and other Western nations, and was recognized as an important value by many Western philosophers throughout history, in particular since the Enlightenment.

TEXT.English: [TAB]While very early societies had a strong state control over the economy, for example in grain storage and distribution, as goods became more complex and trade routes more far reaching, it has become harder for them to exert control over trade. Long distance trade usually took place without state interference by private individuals. For instance, most traders along the silk route organised without any involvement of the involved states. Likewise, states would withdraw from regulating trade and let it pass freely throughout their borders.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Regulated Trade describes a government trade policy that seeks to influence foreign trade to the benefit of its national industries. With the Ming dynasty, China started to close off its economy to foreign trade, and likewise Japan forbade interaction with foreign merchants. Besides protecting local craftsmen, this was also meant to keep out dangerous ideas from abroad. In Europe, increasing trade regulation coincided with colonialism. This particular form of regulated trade, Mercantilism, was focused on importing raw goods from the colonies to produce manufactured goods at the exclusion of foreign economies.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Free Enterprise (also referred to as Laissez-faire economic policy) is an economic system in which transactions between private parties are free from government intervention such as regulation, privileges, tariffs, and subsidies. The doctrine of laissez-faire became an integral part of nineteenth-century European liberalism. Just as liberals supported freedom of thought in the intellectual sphere, so were they equally prepared to champion the principles of free trade and free competition in the sphere of economics. The state was to be merely a passive policeman, protecting private property and administering justice, but not interfering with the affairs of its citizens. Businessmen, and particularly British industrialists, were quick to associate these principles with their own economic interests.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Animism is the religious belief that objects, places, and creatures all possess a distinct spiritual essence. Potentially, animism perceives all thingsâanimals, plants, rocks, rivers, weather systems, human handiwork, and perhaps even wordsâas animated and alive.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Animism is the oldest known type of belief system in the world that even predates paganism. It is still practiced in a variety of forms in many traditional societies. Animism is used in the anthropology of religion as a term for the belief system of many indigenous tribal peoples, especially in contrast to the relatively more recent development of organized religions. Although each culture has its own different mythologies and rituals, "animism" is said to describe the most common, foundational thread of indigenous peoples' "spiritual" or "supernatural" perspectives. The animistic perspective is so widely held and inherent to most animistic indigenous peoples that they often do not even have a word in their languages that corresponds to "animism", or even "religion".

TEXT.English: [TAB]Deification (also called Apotheosis) describes raising a human to the status of a God, either posthumously or during their lifetime. These deified rulers used their divine status to cement their authority, and in turn had the duty to secure the support of the gods for their populace. The most well-known examples of deified rulers are the Egyptian pharaohs. Likewise, Chinese emperors justified their rule by having the Mandate of Heaven. Even though the Greco-Roman world had a more republican outlook on government, the Greeks had a tradition of deifying heroes. With the onset of the Roman Empire, emperors were venerated as gods. A similar tradition existed in many Hindu kingdoms in India, Indochina and Indonesia.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Clergy refers to a hierarchical and institutional structure within a religion. In particular, the clergy itself is the religious leadership present in various organised religions. The names of members of the clergy vary from religion to religion, but their duties are often similar: interpreting existing religious texts and traditions, resolving open religious questions, and administering the religious organisation itself. Since religion is often an important aspect in the legitimisation of secular power, clergy can often be involved in worldly government or even hold such power itself. The various Christian denominations are the most prominent examples here. The leader of Catholic Christianity, the Pope, once exercised control over much of Italy, and bishops and monastic orders used to rule regions of Europe without any dependence on a higher monarch.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Monasticism or monkhood is a religious way of life in which one renounces worldly pursuits to devote oneself fully to spiritual work. Monastic life plays an important role in many Christian churches, especially in the Catholic and Orthodox traditions. Similar forms of religious life also exist in other faiths, most notably in Buddhism, but also in Hinduism and Jainism, although the expressions differ considerably. A religion with focus on monasticism generally is less organised, and concentrated on several monastic orders instead of a central hierarchical order.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Tolerance is the acceptance of an action, object, or person which one dislikes or disagrees with, where one is in a position to disallow it but chooses not to. It has also been defined as "to bear or endure" or "to nourish, sustain or preserve" or as "a fair, objective, and permissive attitude toward those whose opinions, beliefs, practices, racial or ethnic origins, etc., differ from one's own; freedom from bigotry" too. Toleration may signify "no more than forbearance and the permission given by the adherents of a dominant religion for other religions to exist, even though the latter are looked on with disapproval as inferior, mistaken, or harmful."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]There is only one verb to tolerate and one adjective tolerant, but the two nouns tolerance and toleration have evolved slightly different meanings. Tolerance is a state of mind that implies non-judgmental acceptance of different lifestyles or beliefs, whereas toleration indicates the act of putting up with something that one disapproves of. Historically, most incidents and writings pertaining to toleration involve the status of minority and dissenting viewpoints in relation to a dominant state religion.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Sovereignty is the full right and power of a governing body over itself, without any interference from outside sources or bodies. A civilisation that has lost the power to assert its own sovereignty has essentially been destroyed or at least subordinated. On the other hand, Sovereignty itself implies that the civilisation exerts no influence over anything else than its core territory.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A civilisation that is focused on Conquest perpetuates itself through constant military expansion. This is generally the case for societies that inhabit territory insufficient to support it and that are forced to expand to meet their needs. However, expansionism can also be the cultural norms: societies that value military prowess require constant warfare for new generations of leaders to prove their worth. While such a culture can make a civilisation quite adept at warfare, it also leads to economies that are heavily reliant on the influx of wealth brought about by looting and tribute. In consequence, they are at risk of collapse as soon they suffer their first military setback. This can be seen for example by the rapid military expansion of Alexander's Macedon Empire or the Mongol Empire under the Great Khans.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Many Asian civilisations regarded tributary relationships as being more desirable than outright control. Tribute would pacify surrounding powers as well as provide additional income, while requiring no direct military control over defeated enemies. This was especially useful in the relationship with far away powers or those which inhabited rough terrain. Various Chinese dynasties throughout history sought to receive tribute both from the nomads to its north as well as states in South East Asia. The Mongol Empire used the same practice, for example for the fractured states in medieval Russia. In South East Asia, the Mandala system was almost entirely built around tributaries, where important centers such as Ayutthaya, Java or Angkor only kept informal control over their sphere of influence.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Isolationist civilisations have deliberately closed themselves off from the outside world. The reasons for doing so can vary. Sometimes, the desire is to exclude outside merchants from competing with the local economy, but another important reason is to keep out foreign ideas and influences that could threaten the existing social order or government. China stopped its naval program during the Ming dynasty and refused requests for foreign trade, considering itself entirely self-sufficient. In Japan during the Tokugawa Shogunate, the introduction of Western technology and Christianity was considered a threat to population's loyalty to the shogun, and the country completely shut itself off from the world. Joseon Korea similarly was known as the Hermit Kingdom.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In the early modern era, European naval powers began to discover and colonise various parts of the world, beginning in the Americas, but subsequently also Asia and Africa. While the initial process happened without much direction, colonialism quickly became state policy for these civilisations. Under colonialism, vast amounts of wealth were extracted from colonised regions under the exploitation of their native populations to the benefits of their European homelands. Colonialism led to the displacements of large population groups, especially under the transatlantic slave trade, and introduced new plants and animals to parts of the world that had never seen them before. International prestige was as important to colonialism as its economic benefits, and colonial powers would often get into conflicts over their colonies and involve local neighbours.
